title: 110_s2458
content: The Act titled "Community Building Code Administration Grant Act of 2007" authorizes a grant program. The "Community Building Code Administration Grant Act of 2007" authorizes the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development to provide grants to local building code enforcement departments. Grants are awarded competitively based on financial need, benefit to the local jurisdiction, and demonstrated ability to work cooperatively with other local agencies. The maximum grant amount is $1,000,000. The "Community Building Code Administration Grant Act of 2007" authorizes grants to local building code enforcement departments based on financial need, benefit to the local jurisdiction, and ability to work cooperatively with other agencies. The maximum grant amount is $1,000,000. Required elements in grant proposals include... To be eligible for a grant under section 2, a local building code enforcement department must submit a demonstration of needs, a plan for fund use, a plan for local actions to sustain enforcement functions, and a program of public outreach. The local building code enforcement department must have accessible public communication and a plan for timely enforcement of safety violations to be eligible for a grant. SEC. 4. USE OF FUNDS; MATCHING FUNDS. Grants awarded under section 2 can be used to supplement State or local funding for building code enforcement. Funds can be used for staffing, training, certification, accreditation, or capital expenditures. Local building code enforcement departments serving economically disadvantaged communities must provide matching funds of at least 5 percent of the total grant amount. The Act requires communities to provide matching funds of 10% for moderately economically disadvantaged areas and 20% for other communities to receive grants. The Secretary has the authority to waive matching fund requirements based on economic distress levels. The regulations for grant eligibility consider the economic distress level of the local jurisdiction, including factors like growth lag, poverty extent, and housing age. The Secretary may waive matching fund requirements based on economic distress levels. In-kind contributions, not exceeding 50 percent of non-Federal funds, can be considered towards the non-Federal share required. The Secretary may waive matching fund requirements for jurisdictions dedicating building code permitting fees to local enforcement. SEC. 5. RATING AND RANKING OF APPLICATIONS. Eligible applications will be rated and ranked based on criteria in section 6. Points will be awarded on a continuum within each criterion, with the highest points going to the best application. SEC. 6. CRITERIA. Applications will be rated on the degree of cooperation between building code enforcement officials and other local agencies, as well as a community-oriented approach to enforcement. Points will be awarded accordingly. The criteria for rating and ranking applications include a detailed description of capital expenditures, demonstrating reasonable costs, fulfilling jurisdictional needs, and providing joint benefits for various groups or activities. Points are awarded based on the quality of the application. The criteria for rating and ranking applications include a detailed description of capital expenditures that provide cost savings benefits to the jurisdiction. This includes housing preservation, rehabilitation programs, neighborhood improvement programs, and special needs groups. Each application is rated based on the local legislative body's adoption of a plan addressing residential structure conservation and building code enforcement. Points are awarded accordingly. The plan for residential structure conservation and building code enforcement includes proactive measures, interdisciplinary approach, and funding options for repairs and rehabilitation. Points are awarded based on the plan's provisions. The plan provides for only reactive code enforcement and refers to a need to preserve and/or improve existing housing stock without any code enforcement program. No existing plan is mentioned. Each application for code enforcement shall be rated based on its demonstration of cooperative relationships between officials and local agencies, as well as a community-oriented approach to enforcement. Points will be awarded accordingly. Identify interdisciplinary code enforcement programs and team members, describe coordination procedures and services provided. Identify community-oriented code enforcement programs and services. Points awarded based on demonstration of cooperative relationships and community-oriented approach. Proactive Code Enforcement Activities are rated and ranked based on effectiveness of proposed or existing programs operated by building code enforcement programs. Points are awarded accordingly. Encourages repairs and preservation of substandard residences instead of demolition or abandonment, abatement of lead hazards, toxic molds, and displacement of residents, and community clean-up campaigns including recycling events and public clean-up days. Each application will be evaluated based on the jurisdiction's financial and technical ability to support proposed capital expenditures. Points will be awarded based on the demonstration of capacity to utilize and sustain the capital expenditure during the grant term. The grant program funding should be adequate to support the use of grant-financed equipment. The jurisdiction must have the technical capabilities to use and support the equipment. The jurisdiction must have the technical capabilities to use and support grant-financed equipment, such as cell phones or 2-way radios, operated by trained personnel. SEC. 7. EVALUATION AND REPORT. Grant recipients must fully account for and report on the use of grant funds. They are also required to submit a report to the Secretary on the effectiveness of the program and address specific capabilities and functions in local building code enforcement. The report should include lessons learned, plans for program maintenance, and any other criteria requested by the Secretary. The Secretary requires grant recipients to submit interim and final reports to ensure proper use of funds and assess program effectiveness. Reports must be accessible to the public online at no cost. SEC. 8. DEFINITIONS. This Act defines terms such as "building code enforcement department" as the local agency responsible for building code inspection, "jurisdiction" as a local authority enforcing building codes, and "Secretary" as the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development. SEC. 9. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS. Authorization of Appropriations: $100,000,000 authorized annually from 2008 to 2013 for the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development. Up to 5% may be reserved for administrative costs, and funds remain available until expended.
